message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on elastin for help. The cross-linking of lysine residues in elastin gives it the ability to stretch and recoil. Hydroxylation helps stabilize the triple helix formation in collagen, not elastin. Cleavage of disulfide rich terminal regions is not involved in the stretching and recoiling of elastin.

We refer to the textbook "Molecular Biology of the Cell" by Alberts et al. for help. Cross-links between lysine residues in elastin help give it the ability to stretch and recoil. Hydroxylation of proline and lysine rich regions is important for the collagen molecule's structure. Triple helix formation is also a feature of collagen, while cleavage of disulfide rich terminal regions is important for folding and stabilization of many proteins, but not specifically for elastin's stretch and recoil abilities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cross-links between lysine residues give the elastin molecule the ability to stretch and recoil. Hydroxylation of proline and lysine rich regions is important for collagen stability, not elastin. Triple helix formation is also specific to collagen, not elastin. Cleavage of disulfide rich terminal regions is not related to the stretching and recoiling ability of elastin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, cross-links between lysine residues give the elastin molecule the ability to stretch and recoil. Hydroxylation of proline and lysine rich regions allows collagen to form its triple helix structure, triple helix formation is a feature of collagen and cleavage of disulfide rich terminal regions is also a feature of collagen, not elastin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cross-links between lysine residues provide elastin with the ability to stretch and recoil. Hydroxylation of proline and lysine rich regions contributes to the stability and strength of collagen fibers. Triple helix formation is a feature of collagen, not elastin. Cleavage of disulfide rich terminal regions is not a known mechanism for elastin function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cross-links between lysine residues give the elastin molecule its ability to stretch and recoil. Hydroxylation of proline and lysine rich regions occurs in collagen, not elastin. Triple helix formation and cleavage of disulfide rich terminal regions are also not related to the elastic properties of elastin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only cross-links between lysine residues help give the elastin molecule the ability to stretch and recoil. Hydroxylation of proline and lysine regions is important for collagen formation, triple helix formation is also important for collagen formation, and cleavage of disulfide rich terminal regions is not related to stretching and recoiling ability.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cross-links between lysine residues give elastin the ability to stretch and recoil, allowing it to provide elasticity to tissues. Hydroxylation of proline and lysine rich regions is important for collagen formation, triple helix formation is a characteristic of collagen, and cleavage of disulfide rich terminal regions is important for keratinization of skin and hair.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cross-links between lysine residues give the elastin molecule the ability to stretch and recoil. Hydroxylation of proline and lysine rich regions is important for collagen formation, triple helix formation is also important for collagen formation, and cleavage of disulfide rich terminal regions is not a factor in elastin function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on elastin for help. Cross-links between lysine residues give the elastin molecule the ability to stretch and recoil. The other options are related to collagen, not elastin. Hydroxylation of proline and lysine rich regions and triple helix formation are important for collagen stability, while cleavage of disulfide rich terminal regions is important for collagen degradation.
